Description: Base sherd (mended from three fragments) in the form of a lion's paw from Aeolian grey ware pottery stand; light to dull grey fabric with mica and limestone inclusions; top surface largely broken; from the sides at the top emerged an oval ring; the lower half at the rear is broken off, as some attachment at the front above the paw, slight hair-like remains of which remain on the top surface; very worn dark grey slip on exterior.
Curator's comments: The lion's claw was presumably inspired by metalwork.

The item sheered of the front was probably a gorgoneion or panther mask, and the presence of a panther head on a fragment that must be from the same piece, Boston, MFA 86.915, points to the latter. The dimensions of the 'rod' at top right suggest that the fragments of openwork base, 1888,0601.637 and 638 and 1965,0930.441 belong to the same complex. The Boston fragment has a further rod under the lion's paw.
Bibliographic references: Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p.259. no.3)
Johnston 1978 / Pottery from Naukratis: An Exhibition on the Occasion of the 11th International Congress of Classical Archaeology (no. 41)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GL.161)
